- -'adau.definition: fond of, crazy about, favorite thing

examples.english: I'm fond of oranges, I just love oranges.
She's fond of rasp- berries, she just loves raspberries. [GT, MMc]

notes: The initial prefix on this word agrees with the initial prefix on the word naming the thing liked. The possessive prefix refers to the person who likes the thing named. For ex- ample: I-cha-'adau i-gunat "She's fond of salmon"

Clearly related to Warm Springs word átau. When the possessive prefix is a single consonant, there occurs with this word the sequence consonant+glottal stop, which other- wise is not known to occur in Wasco. (In Wasco, a glottal stop normally occurs either at the beginning of a word or between vowels, but not after another consonant.) Hence, it is almost certain that this word was borrowed from Warm Springs to Wasco rather than the other way around.

notes: A platform of 4 forked poles at corners of a rectangle. Poles are laid between each pair of poles, and poles are then laid crosswise on those poles; on these meat is hung, with a fire below to dry it. See graphic.
"Talking small" form of is- c'ikc'ik.

is-elpqtit.definition: bowstring, pot handle, hat cord that comes under the chin

examples.english: You made my fishline for me.
Newspapers are awful liars. [DH]

notes: This noun is shown in WTI.5.3 as shawalaptin, with an abbreviated form of the classifying prefix ish-.
Borrowed from English. -BNA jump

examples.english: I heard a squeal. [Dyk]

ishktälgwipchk.definition: they 2 collected them from water (into it[i-]?)

examples.english: They 2 were collecting them from the river. [WTI.1a.1]

it- -chiqen.definition: old enough to take care of oneself

forms.english: he is old enough to care for himself [Dyk]

notes: Borrowed from English; an English word used with Wasco pre- fixes.

it-baisxádagwax.definition: sin-minded per- son, untrustworthy person [PK 7/11/ 12/56], mind of obscenity [Dyk]

forms.english: he is in the habit of craving for sexual gratifi- cation [Dyk]

notes: This is a stronger form of it- p'aisxádagwax.

examples.english: the sunflower's shade [WTI.5.3]

notes: Hiram Smith [8/23/52] said that this word does not refer to snowpeaks, for which a-kakan is used. PK 8/23/52, however, appar- ently said that this word could refer to the Cascades or the Andes. HS 8/ 8/56 gave this word as in effect a plural of i-bakal.
An alternative form of itbuqux.
This word is obviously related to is-c'emna "staging poles," but it is not clear what the relationship is.

examples.english: I see a tipi. [GT, MMc 6/9/99]

notes: Borrowed to or from Sahaptin c'xwilí.
Refers to chap-like pants that are worn with is-t'ilailaks "breech clout." Each leg was separate and tied at the waist to a belt. [Dyk] Now known as war-dance chaps. [GT, MMc 12/30/97]

forms.english: he's cov- ered with sores [GT, MMc 12/30/97] Apparently not used in singular.

notes: Refers to the long white sacs in a male fish after they have been dried by fire. The undried sacs are it- tq'ín. Dyk gives both this form and ich'aqch'aq for this meaning.

forms.english: buckskin pants [GT, MMc 6/5/98 prefer this to the form itcha'cha' given by HS.]

examples.english: They 2 are put- ting up poles to support the summer house. [PK 4/11/54]

notes: Obviously borrowed from English. The first part may come from "thick," with a reference to "thick shoes"—so called, perhaps, because of their thick soles which prevented people from feeling the ground, as opposed to traditional thin-soled moccasins.
Composed of alakas "mouse" and -lgwilit "appearance."

forms.english: my water [GT 1/14/99] [Note the alternate forms given with possessive prefixes.]

examples.english: ice wa- ter
cold water [HS 7/21/56]

examples.kiksht: Abúd áwachi akním łshtáshq chag̲lqłix chłelbunił dáminwa.
examples.english: In winter the water of a boat or canoe always freezes. [WTII.10.3]

notes: Refers to a group of beings with claws that went into the earth and came out wherever they wished. They were turned into a group of rocks 4 miles east of Spearfish. [Dyk] PK 7/2/55 describes them as "sis- ters" and "children of God."
Borrowed from a European language, most likely English, per- haps via Chinook Jargon.
Appears to refer specifically to human milk. Compare ił-dudush, which may refer to any kind of milk.
May refer to any kind of milk. Compare ił-du, which appears to refer specifically to milk of a human woman.

This was formerly used as a slang term for Paiutes; it is no longer so used. It supposedly means "small heads," as given above, from iq'aqshtaq "head," but a change from -q'- to -g- would normally indicate larger size.

no matter what; nothing will do [Dyk]

What else? [GT, MMc]
again the same, the same again

enough, quit now

nothing, nothing the matter

examples.kiksht: Amuya awachi naika anuya, qengi ch'ala?
examples.english: You'll go or I'll go, how about it?

examples.kiksht: Wax anłuxwa iłk'iwaxmat awachi kwaish, qengi ch'ala?
examples.english: Shall I light the light now or after a while, what do you say? [Dyk]

notes: Apparently a variety of jack salmon.
According to a note appar- ently by David French, this refers to any plant with a scratchy, prickly, or sticky quality. Compare cheqcheq "scratchy."

Originally referred to under- ground lodge, a winter dwelling dug partway into the ground. Now refers to a cellar. [Dyk] What is undoubt- edly the same word is spelled wachélx in Wishram Texts and so pronounced by Gladys Thompson and Madeline McInturff.

The difference in translation may be due to the fact that the Wasco month overlapped two Anglo months. PK 7/10/56 explained the name by saying that in this month people got angry at one another (because they had been confined in winter lodges for some time?) and spoke to one another over their shoulders, without turning around. Compare wachk'én "shoulder."

examples.english: lots of grass
I stuffed the deer with grass.
I stuffed grass in the deer.
He just cut the grass.
In the morn- ing she fixed the hay.
She didn't make/cut hay. [Dyk]

notes: A 4 to 8 inch wooden needle for sewing tuli mats.

wa-ck'ún.definition: dipper [Dyk; PK 6/28/ 51; HS 7/21/56], tin cup [HS 7/21/ 56], cup [GT, MMc]

examples.english: coffee/tea cup [HS 7/21/56]

notes: This word probably referred originally to wooden dippers; in the course of time it has come to be a general word not only for dippers but also for cups, including tea and coffee cups. Hiram Smith, however, used a special expression for coffee or tea cup, given above.

examples.english: one piece of hail, one hailstone [HS 7/21/56]

notes: This appears to be a "talking small" form of a word *wa-chaqwsh, which however has not been found.

examples.english: I'm sitting on the ground.
one year
this year; this ground
The Chinook salmon looked carefully over all the land.
Ground, ground it made itself (as when after the snow melts,ground appears everywhere) [Dyk]
She went to the river.
all along the river [Dyk's transcription: yaka we:mał] [Dyk]

examples.kiksht: G̲angadix galux̲wílaitix adasq'ú idelxam kana'amdmax̲ wimałba.
examples.english: Long ago the Wasco people lived on both sides of the Columbia River. [GT, MMc]

notes: Comment by Phillip Kahclamat: "Sapir said the Columbia is the only one called wimał, but I'd call the Amazon, Mississippi that." Apparently this word refers to large rivers. Compare wi-qał.
"They really burn when they get on you, have stickers on them." [GT 12/29/97]

notes: Most commonly a cry for help. Dyk labels it "a woman's word." See also: anáaa, aláaa

examples.english: Don't, you'll hurt yourself.

notes: A term used by old people or by children, or to children to warm them not to do something dangerous or naughty.
